section.title: Introduction
section.t: Lots of protocols and systems need to name entities, and the DNS "standard" of a series of labels separated with dots has become common, even in systems that are not actually part of the DNS, and involving lookups that do not actually

This document reserves the string "ALT" (short for Alternate) as a Special Use Domain () that should be used in the right-most label position to signify that this name is not rooted in the DNS, and that normal registration and lookup rules do not apply.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: [ WK: I'm really bad at terminology thingies. This section needs much more precision ]

list.t: DNS context: The namespace administered by ICANN. This is the namespace / context that "normal" DNS uses.
non-DNS context: Any other / alternate namespace.

section.title: Background
section.t: The DNS is a distributed hierarchical database, primarily used to map human memorable names to IP addresses. DNS names are composed of a set of LDH (Letter, Digit and Hyphen) labels, separated by dots. The DNS has a single root, and each delegation under this is a Top Level Domain (TLD). TLDs delegate portions of their namespace to nameserver, who may then delegate further. The hierarchical, distributed, caching nature of the DNS has made it the primary resolution system on the Internet.

The success of the DNS means make sit a natural starting point for systems that need to name entities in a non-DNS context. These name resolutions occur in a namespace distinct from the DNS. A number of good examples of these sorts of systems are documented in Special-Use Domain Names of Peer-to-Peer Systems (draft-grothoff-iesg-special-use-p2p-names) [TODO(WK): Make ref].

In many cases these systems build a DNS style inverted tree parallel to the "standard" (IANA?) DNS tree, and use a pseudo-TLD to cause resolution in this alternate namespace, using things like browser plugins, shims in the name resolution process, or simply applications only use this alternate namespace.

In many cases the creators of these alternate namespaces have simply chosen a convenient / descriptive string and started using this. Using names in an alternate namespace may cause issues if they are looked up in the DNS. These include:

list.t: User confusion: If someone emails a link of the form foo.bar.pseudo-TLD to someone who does not have the necessary software to resolve names in the pseudo-TLD namespace, they may become confused.
Excess traffic hitting the DNS root. Lookups may leak out of the pseudo-TLD namespace and end up hitting the DNS root nameservers.
Collisions. If the pseudo-TLD is eventually delegated by ICANN the behavior may be non-deterministic.

section.title: The ALT namespace
section.t: In order to avoid the above issues we reserve the .ALT label. This label should be used as a pseudo-TLD (in the right most (TLD) position of a name) to signify that this is an alternate (non-DNS) namespace.

Alternate namespaces should differentiate themselves from other alternate namespaces by choosing a name and using it in the label position just before the pseudo-TLD. For example, a group wishing create a namespace for [TODO(?): Need something better] Friends Of Olaf they may choose the string "foo" and use any set of labels under foo.alt.

As they are in an alternate namespace they have no significance in the regular DNS context and so should not be looked up in the DNS context. Unfortunately simply saying that "something should not happen" doesn't actually stop it from happening, so we need some rules to deal with these.

list.t: Stub resolvers SHOULD NOT send queries to recursive resolvers for names in the ALT TLD

Recursive resolvers SHOULD return NXDOMAIN (authoritative (AA=1) name errors (RCODE=3)) for queries in the ALT TLD. [ED NOTE: The ALT "TLD" should be added to the RFC6303 "Locally Served Zones" registry.]
The root zone nameservers should either return NXDOMAIN responses, or the ALT TLD should be delegated to "new style" AS112 nameservers (TODO(WK): WK, JA, BD to revive AS112 / AS112-bis).

section.t: Groups wishing to create alternate namespaces SHOULD create their alternate namespace "under" a label that names their namespace, and "under" the ALT label. They SHOULD choose a label that they expect to be unique / descriptive. As there is no registry for the ALT namespace uniqueness is not guaranteed.

Currently deployed projects and protocols that are using pseudo-TLDs (for example, the ".onion" pseudo-TLD (and other labels in draft-grothoff-iesg-special-use-p2p-names ) are not expected to move under the ALT TLD (but may do so if they wish, this is a common resource). Rather, the ALT TLD is being reserved so that future projects of a similar nature have a designated place to create alternate resolution namespaces that will not conflict with the regular DNS context.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: The IANA is requested to add the ALT string to the "Special-Use Domain Name" registry (, and reference this document. In addition, the "Locally Served DNS Zones" () registry should be updated to refernce this document.
